jam.io.hdf
Class DataObject

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--jam.io.hdf.DataObject
Direct Known Subclasses:
DataIDAnnotation, DataIDLabel, FileDescription, FileIdentifier, JavaMachineType, LibVersion, NumberType, NumericalDataGroup, ScientificData, ScientificDataDimension, ScientificDataLabel, ScientificDataScales, Vdata, VdataDescription, VirtualGroup
public abstract class DataObject
extends java.lang.Object

Abstract class to represent a generic HDF data object.

Since:
JDK1.1
Version:
0.5 November 98
Author:
Dale Visser

Vdata

ref

protected short ref
Unique reference number, in case several data elements with the same tag exist. Only makes sense in the context of an HDF file.

offset

protected int offset
Offset from start of file.

bytes

protected byte[] bytes
Actual bytes stored in HDF file.

length

protected int length
Before bytes is created, length of bytes.

file

protected HDFile file
Reference to the particular HDFile this data element resides in.
Constructor Detail

DataObject

public DataObject(HDFile file,
                  short tag)
Creates a new HDF DataObject, belonging to the specified HDFile. My approach is to have a separate HDFile object for each physical HDF file on disk. Each HDFile object handles the bookkeeping of the HDF File Header (see NCSA HDF: Specifications and Developer's Guide v3.2).
Parameters:
file - The file to contain the new object.
tag - The hdf tag of the new object.

DataObject

public DataObject(HDFile file,
                  byte[] data,
                  short reference)
Creates a new DataObject with the specified byte array as the data which will (or does already) physically reside in the file.
Parameters:
file - The file to contain the new object.
data - The byte representation of the data.
reference - The unique value specifying the type of data object.

DataObject

public DataObject(HDFile file,
                  int offset,
                  int length,
                  short reference)
Creates a new DataObject pointing to the offset in the file where its data reside. This option is for when you don't want to hog memory with a large byte array.
Parameters:
file - The file to contain the new object.
offset - The location in file
reference - The unique value specifying the type of data object.
Method Detail

getBytes

public byte[] getBytes()
                throws HDFException
Returns the byte representation to be written at offset in the file.
Throws:
HDFException - thrown if unrecoverable error occurs

setBytes

public void setBytes(byte[] bytes)
Simply sets the bytes, usually performed after a read from a file.

interpretBytes

protected abstract void interpretBytes()
                                throws HDFException
When bytes are read from file, sets the internal fields of the data object.
Throws:
HDFException - thrown if unrecoverable error occurs

getLength

protected int getLength()
Returns the length of the byte array in the file for this data element.

getTag

public int getTag()
Returns a 4-byte representation of the tag, usually defined in the HDF standard, of this item. The tag is a 2-byte integer denoting a unique data object type.

getRef

public short getRef()
Returns a 4-byte representation of the reference number, which is unique for any given tag type in an HDF file. In my code, it is unique, period, but the HDF standard does not expect or require this.

setRef

public void setRef(int reference)

setOffset

public void setOffset(int off)
Called back by HDFile to set the offset information.

getOffset

public int getOffset()

getFile

public HDFile getFile()
Gives the handle to the file holding this object.
